ALL HEADS TURN, A HELICOPTER APPEARS ABOVE THE FIELD
A PHOTO OF SWAMI PRABHAVANANDA YOGANDA
THE HOOKER COMES OUT WITH CRASH'S SHOES
EXT. STREETS OF DURHAM MOMENTS LATER
DEKE AND TOMMY TURN A SPECTACULAR DOUBLE PLAY
EXT. DURHAM BALLPARK THE GAME NIGHT
EXT. A LOCAL BATTING CAGE DAY
EXT/INT. CHEAP BAR IN DOWNTOWN DURHAM
EXT/INT. THE BUS IN FRONT OF THE KINGSTON HOTEL

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: A series of still photos. Black and white. Ancient. BABE RUTH SWINGS -- An icon of American history. His gian upper body balanced delicately on tiny ankles and feet. T huge bat in an elegant follow-through...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TY COBB ROUNDS THIRD -- The most vicious ballplayer of th all, a balletic whirling dervish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACKIE ROBINSON STEALS ROME -- Yogi Berra applies the tag Too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE DIMAGGIO WITH HIS SON in the Yankee clubhouse. Walkin down the runway, Joe in uniform. Number five.

dialogues.speaker: PULLBACK REVEALS
dialogues.text: A WALL COVERED WITH BASEBALL PICTURES behind a small tabl covered with objects and lit candles. A baseball, an old  baseball card, a broken bat, a rosin bag, a jar of pine t also a peacock feather, a silk shawl, a picture of Isador Duncan. Clearly, the arrangement is -- A SHRINE -- And it glows with the candles like some religious altar. We hear a woman's voice in a North Carolina accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in the Church of Baseball. (beat) I've tried all the major religions  and most of the minor ones -- I've  worshipped Buddha, Allah, Brahma,  Vishnu, Shiva, trees, mushrooms, and  Isadora Duncan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN AWAY FROM THE SHRINE across the room. Late afternoon  light spills into the room, across fine old furniture, to small dressing table. A WOMAN applies make up. ANNIE SAVOY, mid 30's, touches up her face. Very pretty,  knowing, outwardly confident. Words flow from her Souther lips with ease, but her view of the world crosses Souther National and International borders. She's cosmic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know things. For instance -- (beat) There are 108 beads in a Catholic  rosary. And -- (beat) There are 108 stitches in a baseball. (beat) When I learned that, I gave Jesus a  chance. (beat) But it just didn't work out between  us. The Lord laid too much guilt on  me. I prefer metaphysics to theology. (beat) You see, there's no guilt in  baseball... and it's never boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE OPENS A CLOSET DOOR -- Dozens of shoes hang from th door. She chooses a pair of RED HIGH HEELS, with thin str She sits on a bench and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which makes it like sex. (beat) There's never been a ballplayer slept  with me who didn't have the best  year of his career. (beat) Making love is like hitting a baseball -- you just got to relax and concentrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE SLIPS ON THE RED HIGH HEELS -- Smoothing her hands her calves as she does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, I'd never sleep with a player  hitting under .250 unless he had a  lot of R.B.I.'s or was a great glove  man up the middle. (beat) A woman's got to have standards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHE HOLDS OUR HER LEGS DISPLAYING THE HEELS, side by side Like a little girl showing off her new shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young players start off full of  enthusiasm and energy but they don't  realize that come July and August  when the weather is hot it's hard to  perform at your peak level. (beat) The veterans pace themselves better.   They finish stronger. They're great  in September. (beat) While I don't believe a woman needs  a man to be fulfilled, I do confess  an interest in finding the ultimate  guy -- he'd have that youthful  exuberance but the veteran's sense  of timing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE STARTS PACKING A HUGE HANDBAG -- With fruit, an off scorebook, binoculars, a radar gun, and lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'see there's a certain amount of  "life-wisdom" I give these boys. (beat) I can expand their minds. Sometimes  when I've got a ballplayer alone  I'll just read Emily Dickinson or  Walt Whitman to him. The guys are so  sweet -- they always stay and listen. (beat) Of course a guy will listen to  anything if he thinks it's foreplay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE TOUCHES PERFUME BEHIND HER EARS and, ever so slight in her cleavage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I make then feel confident. They  make me feel safe. And pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE POSES IN FRONT OF THE MIRROR -- She smoothes her dr along her hips. And puts on a flashy pair of sunglasses.  Stylish and slightly mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I give them lasts a life-time.   What they give me lasts 142 games.   Sometimes it seems like a bad trade. (quickly rebounding) But bad trades are part of baseball --  who can forget Frank Robinson or  Milt Pappas, for Godsakes! (beat) It's a long season and you got to  trust it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE STARTS FOR THE DOOR and grabs her baseball glove

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frame house with porch and lots of trees -- a Thomas Wo house... with a 1959 faded red Volvo in the driveway. ANNIE LEAVES ON FOOT, turning onto the sidewalk of a buco old Durham, North Carolina neighborhood. In the b.g. othe people are heading the same direction ANNIE PULLS A DURHA BULLS BASEBALL CAP from her handbag and pulls it on her h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've tried them all -- I really have -- (beat) and the only church that truly feeds  the soul -- day in, day out -- is  the Church of Baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now visible In the late afternoon sun, a rickety old stad carved into the center of an old Tobacco town. People are arriving on foot from all around... "Rock Around the Clock" by Bill Haley fills the air. CLOSE ON A BASEBALL CLOWN -- MAX PATKIN, 60, at home plat doing his famous Bill Haley routine. A comic pitcher's wi full of twists and goofy choreography.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One o'clock, two o'clock, three  o'clock, rock... Four o'clock, five  o'clock, six o'clock rock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE SITS DOWN IN HER PRIVATE BOX SEAT -- Her chair is w off by a young black boy, JACKSON, 11, who then sits next her. He is her employed errand runner, note sender, and  friend. A GROUP OF GROUPIES ENTERS THE PARK -- 20 year old girl/w dressed in tight pants, tight everything. Friendly, eager, innocent -- THEY WAVE TO ANNIE. FIVE PLAYERS' WIVES AND THREE SMALL CHILDREN sit in a spe box seat behind a small sign "Players' Wives".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven o'clock, eight o'clock, nine  o'clock rock... we're gonna rock  around the clock tonight

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. THE DURHAM BULL DUGOUT
dialogues.text: As Max Patkin continues his routine, players warm up, and THE MANAGER, JOE RIGGINS, 45, known merely as SKIP, short for "Skipper", a chaw of tobacco in his cheek, stands wit his pitching coach, LARRY HOCKETT late 30's, an ex-big le whose body has seen too many cocktail lounges. LARRY ROLLS SOME RED MAN CHEWING TOBACCO into a slab of p bubble gum, carefully folding the corners, tucking it nea together. Larry examines it as they talk -- And shoves th giant chaw into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Ebby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't he warning up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically) No. The guy's professional debut and  he forgets about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better find our bonus baby, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A PLAYER, DEKE, 25, stuffs a hot dog into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen Ebby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouthful of food) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP WHIRLS AND HEADS UP THE TUNNEL into the:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP enters, shouting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebby?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A BARE ASS -- Baseball uniform around the ankles short t-shirt on top, and on top of that the head of EBBY CALVIN LALOOSH, baseball cap on backwards. EBBY is a grea looking energetic man-child with the endless confidence,  naivete and horniness of youth. Life is a party. A YOUNG WOMAN, MILLIE, 20, half nude, is dressing quickly EBBY WHIRLS as Skip enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Game starts in four minutes! (beat) Why ain't you warm?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am warm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fining you a hundred dollars.  Jesus, Ebby, this is your professional  debut tonight -- you know how many  guys out there'd give blood to be in  your shoes an' you're leavin' your  fastball in the locker room for some  piece of ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLIE LOOKS OUT FROM BEHIND A BAT RACK -- Outraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip, It's me! I'm not some quote  piece of ass unquote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Millie, jeez, sorry -- I didn't  recognize ya. Don't take it personal  but if I catch you in here again  you're banned from the ballpark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't ban me from the ballpark  'cause Daddy donated the scoreboard  and if you banned me he might take  the scoreboard away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatta we need a scoreboard for? We  haven't scored any runs all year (tough, to Ebby) Get your ass out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Skip starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Boss, I got a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops, exasperated) What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I need a nickname? I think  I need a nickname. The great ones  have nicknames -- somethin' like Oil  Can or Catfish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip stares at him. He can't believe this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya got three minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP WHIRLS AND HEADS BACK OUT TO THE FIELD -- And Ebby  unperturbed, turns his attention back to Millie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got time for another quickie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you got a game to pitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we got three minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAX PATKIN STILL FLAILING AWAY to "Rock Around the Clock"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the clock strikes two, three,  and four and the band slows down  we'll yell for more, gonna rock around  the clock tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE LOOKS THROUGH HER BINOCULARS -- Studying the player warming up casually on the sidelines as Patkin winds up h act. P.O.V. A LATIN PLAYER PLAYING PEPPER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number twenty-two's thighs are just  great. Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading the program) Jose Galindo. He hit .314 at Lynchburg  last year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three-fourteen? Hmmm...  Look't those  thighs, Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO MAX PATKIN -- He finishes his routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna rock, gonna rock around the  clock tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WOMAN ANNOUNCER, MARYLOU, 30, speaks into the P.A. mike

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hear it for Max Patkin --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause as Patkin takes his bows, leaves the field, shak hands with a the BULL MASCOT LEADING THE APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Greatest Show on Dirt" -- your  own Durham Bulls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ANOTHER PLAYER -- MICKEY MCFEE, 23, black. Smoki a cigarette -- always smoking a cigarette. He snuffs out cigarette and RUNS onto the field with the rest of the te as -- EBBY ENTERS THE DUGOUT from the runway. Larry and Skip  encourage their players running onto the field. Ebby is t to get the zipper on his fly unstuck. He smiles broadly a Skip and Larry, and grabs his glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm there, Skip, I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE RADIO ANNOUNCER, TEDDY CULLINANE, 50, leans into the  radio mike of a very small local station. Next to him is local SPORTSWRITER, WHITEY SHERRARD, 40. Between them the seen a million minor league players come and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this guy LaLoosh worth a hundred  grand? I hear he's a quart low?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering the mike) He's left handed. Whattya expect? (on the air) The Bulls are off to a slow start  having dropped their first three  games, but hope to turn it around  tonight with the professional debut  of the heralded young left hander,  Ebby Calvin LaLoosh. (beat) Stepping in for the Peninsula White  Sox is leadoff hitter Willie Foster

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE TO ANNIE'S BOX SEAT -- Millie has joined Annie and  Jackson. Clearly, the younger women look up to Annie for  wisdom and insight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Millie, you've got to stay out of  the clubhouse. It'll just get  everybody in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got lured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't get "lured". Women never  get lured. They're too strong and  powerful for that. Now say it -- "I  didn't get lured and I will take  responsibility for my actions".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I didn't get lured and I will take  responsibility for my actions".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's better. (to Jackson) Got the radar ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACKSON AIMS A RADAR GUN at the plate. THE PENINSULA WHITE SOX LEADOFF HITTER steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The word on LaLoosh is that the good  looking young lefty has a major league  fastball but sometimes has problems  with his control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EBBY CALVIN LALOOSH WINDS UP and fires. The pitch sails o the batter's head, over the catcher's head, over the back and CRASHES INTO THE PRESS BOX.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE ANNOUNCER AND SPORTSWRITER CRASH to the floor as the  ball smashes into their booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP SPITS TOBACCO, mumbles flatly to Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts to EBBY) C'mon big 'un, you're okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE'S BOX SEAT -- She turns to Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninety-five miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks great, just great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CATCHER TALKS TO EBBY, trying to calm him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?! Lighten up  a little. Awright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to catcher) Hey -- what's your name again -- I'm  bad with names --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed. You want me to write it on my  chest? Jesus ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Hey, Ed, I got a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the beef sitting behind the  third base dugout?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) That's Annie Savoy. Nice eh? But  that's more woman than you ever  dreamed of, Rook. She could kick  your ass and have you for breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CATCHER RETURNS to the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHITEY AND TEDDY WARILY CLIMB back to their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One ball and no strikes to Willie  Foster...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EBBY'S NEXT PITCH HITS FOSTER in the ribs. He crumples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE'S BOX SEAT -- She's writing a note. She hands it to Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this to Ebby in the dugout  between innings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says he's not bending his back on  his follow-through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACKSON RUNS OFF with the note. Annie turns to Millie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well let's get down to it, honey --  how was he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he fucks like he pitches.   Sorta all over the place

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit "Rock Around the Clock" --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUICK MONTAGE OF EBBY'S FIRST GAME -- Strikeouts and wild pitches. A young, gifted, uncontrollable thrower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the chimes ring five, six and  seven -- We'll be right in Seventh  Heaven, Gonna rock around the clock  tonight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EBBY UNLEASHES A WILD ONE -- And decks the Bull Mascot. EBBY IN THE DUGOUT READS THE NOTE from Annie. EBBY STRIKES OUT a Peninsula batter. EBBY UNLEASHES ANOTHER WILD ONE and a batter hits the dir End "Rock Around the Clock" and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP WALKS THROUGH THE PLAYERS ROOM -- Players are up, jo irreverently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Lefty, hold 'em to 12 runs every  night, you'll win 20 --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he might be serious) Had 'em all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A DURHAM PLAYER SITTING HALF DRESSED in front of his lock A PICTURE OF JESUS hangs amidst his gear. The player, JIM 25, has a Bible and prays softly to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Lord, thank you for being with  us tonight, thank you for protecting  us from injury and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEKE WALKS BY, shaking Jimmy irreverently as he prays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, wake up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICKEY (A BLACK) COMPLAINS TO TONY as they undress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This league is racist, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time you go 0 for 4 you think  the league is racist -- face it,  Mick, you're an equal opportunity  "out".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MANAGER'S OFFICE -- A tiny cubicle, a desk, phone Lar joins him with the pitching charts. Skip studies the char

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walked eighteen?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a league record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Struck out eighteen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: League record. (beat) And he hit the Radio Announcer, a  Sportswriter, and the Bull Mascot  twice -- also league records -- (beat) Joe, the guy's got some serious shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DOOR OPENS -- A PLAYER ENTERS, in street clothes, car his suitcases. CRASH DAVIS, 30, older than the other play And different. More than just opinions, he actually has a point of view. A career minor leaguer, hanging on whereve he can get a job. Unlike Ebby -- Crash knows a lot about world without baseball. Also unlike Ebby -- he loves base desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who're you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash speaks slowly, with a trace of cynicism and pride,  like an old warrior who knows he's just a hired gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the player to be named later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Skip looks out, half dressed, from his cubicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash Davis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Crash Davis. (beat, then nonstop) And you, Larry Hockett, should  recognize me 'cause five years ago  in the Texas League when you were  pitching for El Paso and I was hitting  cleanup for Shreveport, you hung a  curve on an 0-2 pitch of a 3-2 game  in bottom of the 8th and I tattooed  it over the Goodyear Tire sign, beat  you 4-3 -- and I got a free wheel  alignment from Goodyear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering) Oh yeah. I shoulda throwed a slider.   Damn, Crash, how're ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Joe Riggins. Sit down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too old for this shit. Why the  hell am I back in "A" ball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause of Ebby Calvin LaLoosh. (beat) The Big Club's got a hundred grand  in him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a million dollar arm and a  five cent head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- we had the gun on him tonight --  the last five pitches he threw were  faster than the first five. 96 miles  an hour, 98, 97, 97. 97. (beat) He's got the best young arm I've  seen in 30 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he ain't quite sure which plane  he's on, y'know what I mean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been around, you're smart, you're  professional, you know what it takes -- (beat) We want you to mature the kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Mature" ain't a fuckin' verb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to college or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want you to room with him on the  road and stay on his case all year. (beat) He can go all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where can I go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can keep going to the ballpark  and keep gettin' paid to do it. (beat) Beats hell outta working at Sears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sears sucks, Crash, I tried it once.   Sold Lady Kenmores -- it's nasty,  nasty work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if it's the Carolina League --  this is a chance to play everyday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) You don't want a player, you want a  stable pony. My Triple A contract  gets bought out so I can hold the  Flavor o' the Month's dick in the  bus leagues?! (angrily) Fuck this fucking game... I fuckin'  quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH RISES TO LEAVE -- Picks up his luggage, and turns t Skip and Larry before exiting. A deep breath

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who we play tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. They know, they share the inability to quit the gam They're all clinging to the Church of Baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston-Salem. Batting practice at  4:30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH LEAVES and as he does -- Ed (the catcher) enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Ed, shut the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does. Remains standing. He can see it coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the toughest job a manager  has, Ed... (deep breath) But the organization has decided to  make a change -- we're releasing you  from your contract...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON ED -- Silent. Motionless. Empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH PUTS HIS BAG IN A LOCKER as other players return fr the shower. Crash watches as EBBY SOAKS HIS ELBOW IN A TU OF ICE WATER as the sports writer, Whitey, interviews him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it feel to get your first  professional win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It feels "out there". A major rush.   I mean it doesn't just feel "out  there" but it feels out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopeless. Utterly fucking hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud country music in the players' hangout and pickup spo It's full of players and lots of young women.

dialogues.speaker: MILLIE SITS DOWN NEXT TO YET ANOTHER PLAYER, TONY, 25
dialogues.text: He's slick, urban, smooth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Millie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Tony. I play left field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE SITS IN THE CORNER at her own table. Max Patkin, lo spiffy in a turtle neck sweater and double breasted blaze sits down next to her. Old friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love the game, Annie, love it (dead serious) When I die I'm gonna have my ashes  sprinkled around a pitcher's mound  in some ballpark somewhere -- (beat) -- and I'll have a few ashes saved  for the rosin bag so I'll still be  in the game after I'm gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a sweet idea --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COCKTAIL WAITRESS DELIVERS another round to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't order this, honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she points) He did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.O.V. Crash davis sitting alone in the other corner. He  waves, and smiles easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Max) Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Oh Crash... you do make speeches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash puts the bat down, heads out the gate. She follows. A LITTLE LEAGUE TEAM ARRIVES -- Twenty-five 10 year olds uniform with a couple PARENT COACHES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, are you Crash Davis! Can I have  a autograph?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH STOPS TO SIGN AUTOGRAPHS amidst 25 Little Leaguers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he signs autographs) Well, Annie, your place or mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got me all confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A batter has two tenths of a second  to decide whether to swing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a real batter. I'm a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, when are you guys gonna start  winning? You're terrible!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a long season, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY A VOICE -- Nuke pulls up, gets out of his Porsch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! (coming over) What're you guys doing here --  stealing my girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Nuke, would I do a thing like  that? (to the little leaguers) Hey kids, this is the great Ebby  Calvin "Nuke" LaLoosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Nuke, it's Nuke! Can I have  your autograph?! Etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No prob, kids --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly Nuke is swept up into a sea of Little League Crash smiles as he turns Annie and the kids over to Nuke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you guys at the ballpark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash leaves Annie with Nuke and 25 Little Leaguers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN AGING SHELBY MUSTANG CONVERTIBLE -- The paint's fading couple dings in the body, but loaded under the hood. CRASH PUNCHES HIS TAPE DECK -- Sam Cooke's "You Send Me". ANNIE BITES HER FIST watching Crash leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds of lovemaking in a darkened room lit only by a few candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yesnmmmmyes... (beat) Oh my... (several beats) Oh, that was just fabulous, Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several beats of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He flips on a lamp near the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Nuke. You said "Crash".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say "Crash". I said Nuke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said "Crash".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, don't ever listen to a woman  when she's making love. They'll say  the strangest things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said "Crash".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you rather me be making love  to him, using your name, or making  love to you, using his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke considers this fabulous logic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah maybe you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see how nice things are when we  go slow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke sighs; and lets his head sink in the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm, hmmm. (beat) You shoulda seen how many people  came to the airport to see me off.   When I got drafted first it was the  happiest day of my Father's life. (beat) He likes baseball more than I do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can learn to like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to be the host of Dance  Fever, somethin' like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know if you make it to the Bigs  you could still become the host of  Dance Fever. Baseball's a good  stepping stone for things like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, I never thought of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweetly) There is a lot of things you never  thought of, sweetie -- now get some  rest for tonight's game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke rests his head on Annie's shoulder. His eyes are wid open and full of nervous energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE ON A PAY PHONE -- In his uniform. Players warming up the background as the ground crew prepares the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Dad? This is Ebby. (beat) Yeah, I know, I know -- you got the  Durham papers yet? Well I been a  little wild... (defensively) These hitters down here are better  than the ones in high school... (trying to change  subject) How's Mom? Yeah? Well I am trying  hard... I am bending my back... you're  not coming down' here to visit just  yet, are you? (beat) Can I talk to Mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MAYOR OF DURHAM AND THE CITY COUNCIL stand at a mike front of home plate. 300 LITTLE LEAGUERS in uniform are l up along the foul line, restrained by a rope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the Mayor of  Durham, the honorable Mutt Clark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MAYOR STEPS to the mike.  A classic Southern mayor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the "Atlantic Seaboard  Tobacco Growers City Council Little  League Cash Drop Night"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the honorable Mutt Clark drones on -- we INTERCUT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE IS WARMING UP TO PITCH -- Crash and Larry watch him  closely, giving advice. As Nuke delivers --.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive off your back leg. You pitch  with your legs as much as your arms --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MANGY DOG EATS FROM A DISH provided by the players. A c kids sit with the players. MILLIE SITS DOWN NEXT TO A PLAYER -- BOBBY, 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Millie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSE FASHIONS A SMALL CROSS OUT OF CHICKEN BONES and rubs on his bat. Bobby notices this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chicken bone cross take the curse  off this bat and bring me hits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a God damn witch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. A switch hitting witch. Very  common in Puerto Rico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will that work for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you believe in Voodoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm 0 for 16! Gimme some of that  shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY HOLDS OUT HIS BAT for Jose to rub with the cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that is not belief. That is  desperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, God damn it, gimme some!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO THE MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL -- Hair and hats blowi from the chopper turbulence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...five, four, three, two, one...  let 'er go! One thousand big ones!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE HELICOPTER DUMPS HUNDREDS OF DOLLAR BILLS above the f The night sky fills with fluttering money THE ROPE IS DRO THREE HUNDRED LITTLE LEAGUERS charge across the infield t the falling money, scooping it up wildly, brawling, shovi clawing for the cash. As the money flutters down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE ROSIN BAG on the mound. A hand picks it up. Puffs of rosin "smoke". Nuke is on the mound. NUKE NERVOUSLY WALKS AROUND THE MOUND -- Just before the  first batter. He picks up the rosin bag. Digs a slot for lead foot to land. And CRASH APPROACHES, in full gear, ma tipped up on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try to strike everybody out. (beat) Strikeouts are boring. They're  Fascist. Throw some ground balls,  it's more Democratic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH TURNS AND HEADS TO THE PLATE and we hear the beginn of Nuke's interior monologue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this guy know, eh? If he's so  great why's he been in the minors  for ten years? And if he's so hot  how come Annie wants me instead of  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH TURNS AROUND HALF WAY TO THE PLATE and returns to t mound, as if he knows everything Nuke's thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And listen, meat. You don't know  shit. If you want to get to the Show,  you'll listen to me. She only wants  you 'cause she can boss you around,  got it? (beat, complete tone  change) Relax, have a ball out here. This  game's fun, okay? Fun, God damn it. (beat) And don't squeeze the ball so tight.  It's an egg. Hold it like an egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH SMILES -- And trots back to the plate. NUKE'S P.O.V. The first batter steps in. Crash gives the  sign for the pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fun? What's he know about fun? (beat) Why's he calling for a curveball? I  wanta bring heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shake off the pitch. Throw what you  wanta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE SHAKES OFF THE PITCH -- Here comes Crash back out to the mound before Nuke's thrown a pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you shaking me off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanta throw the heater to announce  my presence with authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "To announce your fucking presence  with authority"? This guy's a first  ball fastball hitter. He's looking  for heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he ain't seen my heat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, meat, give him your heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH RETURNS ONE MORE TIME to behind the plate. CRASH CROSSES THE PLATE, past the hitter. He speaks to th opposing leadoff batter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fastball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's he always call me "Meat"? I'm  the guy driving a Porsche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS UP AND DELIVERS -- A fastball. THE LEADOFF HITTER TEES OFF on the pitch and sends a line shot over the right field fence. CLOSE ON BILLBOARD -- "Hit Cow, Win Steak" sign, The home run hits the cow on a target painted on the cow's rump. The COW'S MOUTH OPENS AND MOOS. THE BATTER STANDS AND WATCHES the home run, admiring the  shot, enjoying the moment. CRASH GETS IN HIS FACE instant and gets very tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you lookin' at?! You're  showing up my pitcher, bush -- get  your ass in gear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BATTER TAKES OFF ON A HOME RUN TROT -- Slightly scare AND CRASH HEADS TO THE MOUND where Nuke watches the Mooin Cow and the circling batter with dismay. Crash smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy hit the shit outta that one, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I held it like an egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An' he scrambled the son of a bitch. (beat) Having fun yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having a blast. (beat) God, that sucker teed off on it just  like he knew I was gonna throw a  fastball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH SMILES -- Drops the mask, returns behind the plate. NUKE SIGHS -- Takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think. Just throw. Don't think.  Just throw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE'S WINDUP AND DELIVERY -- A fastball. A powerful, cle overwhelming fastball. Strike one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, that was beautiful. What'd I  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS UP AND DELIVERS HIS NEXT PITCH -- A monster. A Ebby Calvin "Nuke" LaLoosh fastball. Twenty feet wide of plate. THE BULL MASCOT DIVES FOR COVER -- The ball hits the bat  rack. Bats go flying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE IN HER BOX SEAT -- Jackson with the radar gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear... easy honey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninety-five miles an hour...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO NUKE -- Pacing the mound. Looks in for the sign. NUKE PITCHES AGAIN -- The batter lines a single to left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, Skip and Larry are talking  about me. Don't get anybody warm in  the pen yet. I'm okay. I'm having  fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE PITCHES AGAIN -- The batter lines a single to right. NUKE'S P.O.V. THE BULLPEN -- TWO PITCHERS start warming u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't yank me in the first, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE'S P.O.V. -- THE MANAGER comes out to the mound to ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MANAGER AND CRASH MEET NUKE on the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pull me, Skip. I'll settle  down. I'm okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fatherly) Relax, Nuke, Relax... (to Crash) What kinda stuff's he got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I haven't caught  anything yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you thinking about out here,  Nuke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying not to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. But just 'cause you ain't  s'posed to think don't mean you ain't  s'posed to use your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP SLAPS NUKE ON THE ASS in a gruff, reassuring way, an returns to the dugout. Leaving Nuke and Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have some fun, God damn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH SMILES -- And as he returns to the plate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE WATCHES IN THE STANDS with Jackson and the radar gu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go again, Jackson, hold on  tight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit Professor Longhair rock and roll... and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE DELIVERS -- A batter grounds out weakly. DURHAM AT BAT -- DUGOUT -- Crash lets Jose rub his bat wi a chicken bone cross. Then steps to the plate and -- CRASH HITS A LONG HOME RUN -- And circles the bases. NUKE DELIVERS -- A line drive nearly undresses him. Runne circle the bases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SHOWERS -- Naked bodies in the steamy room. No joking around. A team on losing streak. SUDDENLY SKIP STEPS INTO THE SHOWER in his uniform and an throws an armload of bats into the shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody not outta the shower in ten  seconds gonna get fined a hundred  bucks. One, two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SHOWER EMPTIES in seconds. Players grab a seat, and: WHITEY THE SPORTSWRITER ENTERS as he does every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No press for five minutes, Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm doing a column on the Myth of  Sisyphus as manifest in a minor league  losing streak, Joe, and I thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP PICKS UP A CHAIR AND FIRES IT AT WHITEY -- The chair crashes into a locker. Whitey hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I ever need a brain transplant  I'll choose a sportswriter 'cause  that way I'd be getting a brain that's  never been used.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple snickers from the players. Skip whirls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you laughing at?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The Durham Bulls sit and stand quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys lollygag the ball around  the infield, ya lollygag you're way  to first, ya lollygag in an' outta  the dugout. You know what that makes  ya (beat) Lollygaggers. What's our record,  Larry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're eight and sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight and sixteen?! How'd we ever  win eight? (beat) Jose, what's this sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP FLASHES THROUGH A SEQUENCE of signs. Hand to face, h to belt, hand brushes letters, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the steal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong. That's the bunt. This is the  steal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP FLASHES QUICKLY ANOTHER SEQUENCE -- Hand to face, ha to hands. He speaks rapidly -- a private language.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Face is "skin to skin". Skin starts  with "S". "S" stands for steal if it  follows the indicator which is hand  to eye 'cause the word "indicator"  starts with an "I" so I figure "eye" -- (touches his eye) -- would remind you of "I" for  indicator to indicate that what  follows is the sign. I figure wrong --  You're a buncha lollygaggers. (beat) This is a simple game. (beat) ya throw the ball, ya hit the ball,  ya catch the ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON FACES OF THE PLAYERS -- Sitting silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SIX PLAYERS' WIVES WAIT in a cluster. Three of them h SMALL CHILDREN. The children are crying. The long-suffering women try to calm the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby went hitless again. He's gonna  be in a terrible mood... terrible.   How'd Mickey do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got two hits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK INSIDE THE LOCKER ROOM -- Skip is winding down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't win at home -- how we gonna  win on the road? We got a twelve day  road trip starting tomorrow. (beat) Bus leaves at six in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP HEADS BACK INSIDE his little office with Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSIDE SKIP'S OFFICE -- He and Larry open a couple beers. THE DOOR OPENS -- BOBBY ENTERS wearing only a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Bobby, shut the door. (he does) This is the toughest job a manager  has... (beat) But the organization has decided to  make a change --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skip, I know I'm in a slump but I  hit the ball hard tonight, right at  'em. A couple flares drop in, and  I'm back in the groove!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nearly naked 25 year old man pleads helplessly -- his career is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PLAYERS EXIT -- The Groupies wait in a cluster. The w wait in another group. Bobby's wife sees Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to child) There's Daddy! Wave to Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- P.O.V. BOBBY COMING OUT OF THE CLUBHOUSE -- Another pl has his arm around Bobby, consoling him. The wife knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DURHAM BULLS TEAM BUS is parked. Luggage is loaded. S players arriving, escorted by wives and girlfriends. ANNIE BIDS NUKE GOODBYE -- Off to the side. She pulls  something from her handbag and hands it to Nuke. A pair o WOMEN'S RED PANTIES, with lace and frills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to wear these on the road  trip when you pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll fit snugly against your balls  in such a wonderful way that you'll  start seeing things differently -- plus they'll remind you of me which  is better than thinking about those  nasty hitters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Annie, I don't know --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been pitching out of the wrong  side of your brain. These'll help  move things to the right side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big League pitchers don't use these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They did when they were in the  Carolina League.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE STUFFS THE PANTIES in his pocket, bewildered. A smal kiss from Annie, and he hurries to the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PLAYERS THROW THEIR GEAR into their travel bags. A PAPER BEER CUP IS TAPED TO THE WALL -- With a sign: "Married men deposit wedding rings here for road trips". CLOSE ON THE CUP -- A ring is dropped in, and another, an We begin hearing Annie's VOICE OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman should never ask questions  about road trips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TEAM BUS PULLS OUT -- Wives and girlfriends head back their apartments, leaving: ANNIE WALKING BACK ROME -- Several blocks to her house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men don't realize that women always  know when they've been unfaithful. (beat) The fact is, upon exact moment of  penetration -- the woman knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS ANNIE WALKS BACK through Durham...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TEAM BUS ROLLS through the North Carolina landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This sort of spiritual awareness can  be a mixed blessing, especially if  you're dating a ballplayer. I believe  a woman oughta take care of her man  so thoroughly that he can go on the  road for a few days without having  the desire to search out another  pair of panties (self-aware) That is probably, however, my most  ridiculous belief. (sigh) I just hope the boys start winning  soon. In some profound way I fear  that a last place team is a reflection  on its women...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BUS ROLLS through North Carolina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP SITS IN THE FRONT of the bus, doing a crossword puzz LARRY READS A BOOK -- "How to Make a Million Dollars in R Estate with No Money Down". DEKE TURNS UP HIS TAPE DECK -- George Jones sings "He Sto Loving Her Today". MICKEY TURNS UP HIS TAPE DECK across the aisle -- Aretha  Franklin sings "R-E-S-P-E-C-T". DEKE TURNS HIS VOLUME LOUDER -- Mickey does likewise, and soon we have DUELING TAPE DECKS. C & W going head to with R & B. A cacophony. SKIP LEAPS TO HIS FEET, WHIRLS and shouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got one word to say to you -- Shut  up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. And then from the back of the bus, some soft, gentle, but slightly dissonant guitar chords. THE BACK OF THE BUS -- Nuke sits across the aisle from Cr who's re-reading Thomas Pynchon. Nuke has a guitar and is struggling with some chords to "Try a Little Tenderness". He butchers the chords and the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing softly) Oh she may get wooly, women do get  wooly, because of all the stress...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in disgust) Gimme that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH STRONGARMS THE GUITAR from Nuke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate people who get the words wrong.   It ain't "woolly" it's "weary" and  it nobody's got stress, they're  wearing a dress. (beat) Listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH WHIPS THROUGH THE FIRST FEW BARS of the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sings softly) Oh she may be weary, Young girls do  get weary, Wearing the same old  dress...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE SHOVES THE GUITAR back at Nuke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you don't like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you don't respect yourself,  which is your problem, but you don't  respect the game -- and that's my  problem. (beat) You got a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gift. When you were a baby the  gods reached down and turned your  left arm into a thunderbolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke looks at his left arm rubs his shoulder curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a Hall of Fame arm but you're  pissing it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't pissing nothing away -- I  got a Porsche already. A 944 with  A.C. and a quadraphonic Blaupunkt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need a quadraphonic  Blaupunkt -- you need a curve ball. (beat) In the Show, everybody can hit the  fastball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been in the Majors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Deke overhear this and turn around. And Crash ge wistful, lyrical, and even slightly hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in the Show for 21 days, once. (beat) It was the greatest 21 days of my  life. You never touch your luggage  in the show -- somebody else handles  your bags. It's great. (beat) The ballparks are like cathedrals,  the hotels all have room service,  the women have long legs and brains --  it's a smorgasbord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women are hot, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- and so are the pitchers.  They throw ungodly breaking stuff in  the Show -- exploding sliders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke, Tony, and Deke murmur in awe at Crash's pronounceme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could be one of those guys --  but you don't give a fuck, Meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it I'm sick of you calling  me "Meat"! You wanta step outside!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH HOPS TO HIS FEET as the bus barrels along, grabbing Nuke by the collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke quickly has second thoughts -- Crash can be terrifyi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Wait a minute. Calm down, Crash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke sits back down. Calms. Reaches for a baseball sittin nearby. He hands the ball to Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teach me how to throw a breaking  ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash takes the ball gently and speaks softly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I was saying ya hold it like an  egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the bus rolls through the country: A LATE 60'S OLDS CONVERTIBLE ROARS PAST -- Max Patkin at wheel. He waves at the team bus and honks. The opening bars on the National Anthem -- "Oh Say Can Yo See" And Max roars off through the rolling green-landscape... Hit Hank Williams music to play over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAX PATKIN COACHES THIRD in his comic routine, now, for t Winston-Salem team, as Durham is in the field. A WINSTON-SALEM BATTER lines a double off the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEDDY THE ANNOUNCER re-creates the game for broadcast wit several second delay. HIS ASSISTANT (P.A. ANNOUNCER FROM THE BALLPARK) has a ph to her ear, and writes down each play on a piece of paper holding it up for Teddy who enhances shamelessly in his O THE AIR "play by play". CLOSE ON PAPER -- His assistant writes "DOUBLE TO LEFT". TEDDY HITS A TINY MALLET against a jar. Thunk. The sound ball hitting bat. He punches one of several tape cassette cued up. A crowd roars. An array of special effects is at his fingertips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the air) ...double off the wall by Higgins,  and once again the Durham pitchers  are unable to get the first out of  the inning...

dialogues.speaker: HIS ASSISTANT WRITES ANOTHER NOTE
dialogues.text: Thunk -- The mallet again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the air) Line drive to center -- a diving  stab by McFee -- ohhhh!  Ball gets  by his glove, another run in and the  crowd loves it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PUNCHES A CASSETTE -- A crowd roars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus rolls through a small town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE TEAM BUS PULLS IN -- Players stagger off, half asleep

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the air) Bulls will attempt to end a six game  losing streak against the Greensboro  Astros with Nuke LaLoosh on the  hill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE DRESSES FOR THE GAME -- He pulls the RED PANTIES out his bag. Looks around the clubhouse. Nobody sees them. He embarrassed anyway -- and stuffs them back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GREENSBORO BALLPARK DAY
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS AND DELIVERS -- The batter swings, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEDDY AND HIS ASSISTANT -- A note is held up, "Single"-- THUNK -- The mallet strikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the air) Base hit centerfield off LaLoosh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIS ASSISTANT (ON THE PHONE) SCRAWLS another quick note. THUNK THUNK THUNK -- A rapid sequence of the mallet strik the percussive box, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the air) That closes the book on LaLoosh today,  5 earned runs, 5 hits, 5 strikeouts,  5 walks, 5 wild pitches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP REMOVES NUKE FROM THE GAME and he heads for the show

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE SITS WITH MILLIE at the kitchen table, listening to the radio. Annie sighs. Millie consoles her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE IN THE SHOWERS ALONE -- Letting the water run over h The voice of Teddy an the air, editorializing shamelessly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the air) It's time to tell it like it is,  sports fans -- and this is the most  wretched road trip I've seen in 20  years, and possibly the worst Durham  team in half a century. (beat) Where are the great Bull players of  yesteryear? Where are the Footsie  Blakes, the Digger O'Dells, the Gus  Palowitzes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEDDY'S VOICE PLAYS OVER road trip images: NUKE STARTS TO PUT ON THE RED PANTIES -- Changes his mind and hides them again. THE TEAM BUS rolling across North Carolina. THE TEAM BUS at a drive through hamburger stand somewhere the Smoky Mountains.  Sack after sack of fast food is pas through the window to Skip. THE TEAM BUS PULLS INTO YET ANOTHER HOTEL and this time, Bus with a sign -- "Holiday on Ice" pulls in next to them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the air) Is the modern athlete a pale imitation  of the great old warriors? Only Crash  Davis stands out this year, begging  the question, "What are these boys  thinking about, 'cause it sure ain't  baseball".

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. THE BUS IN FRONT OF THE KINGSTON HOTEL
dialogues.text: As the players rise in the bus, Deke is trying to work up excitement about the "Holiday on Ice" bus from which twen great looking women ice skaters are getting off. P.O.V.  HOLIDAY ON ICE GIRLS getting off the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ice skaters. God. Look't em. that's  what we need, y'know -- one night  with some skaters and we can get  back on track...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need a night off just to stop our  losing streak. We need a rainout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get us a rainout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 90 degrees, there ain't been a  cloud in the sky in weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred bucks says I can get us a  rainout tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAB PULLS UP in the dark. Late at night. The cab leaves and the four men climb over the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH PULLS THE LID OFF A BOX -- Several valve handles. Crash turns several handles with an iron bar, and... THE SPRINKLER SYSTEM COMES TO LIFE -- And suddenly the fi is covered with the clicking of rain-bird sprinklers, thr long slow arcs of water across the entire field.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: THE FOUR PLAYERS sit on the scoreboard, watching the  sprinklers flood the field. A six-pack is passed around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A QUAGMIRE ON THE INFIELD -- The Kingston GENERAL MANAGER stands in the muck with his ground crew. Wheelbarrows,  shovels, sand is piled around. It's hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it! Vandals. Damn kids!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't get it ready by game time,  boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General Manager studies the field. Hopeless. He looks up at the sky. Cloudless, sunny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his assistant) Call the radio and the paper. (with disgust) The game's been rained out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Organ music -- "The Blue Danube Waltz".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "HOLIDAY ON ICE" in its matinee performance. The beautifu leggy women skating to the "Blue Danube Waltz". TEN OF THE DURHAM BULLS sit in the front row. Nuke, Deke, Tommy, others, but not Crash. Tony waves to a skater. THE SKATER WAVES BACK as she swirls past the Bulls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEKE ICES THE CHAMPAGNE -- In the b.g. Tommy is blow dryi his hair. Mickey puts the finishing touches on his outfit Several other players get ready to party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Par--ty! I blew a whole day's meal  money for this champagne seven  dollars, man, it better be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For seven bucks it better be some  serious shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it, eh? When are they  coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys lounge around nervously, trying to be casual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A STEAK DINNER set down in front of Crash. Nuke hands Crash a hundred dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is from Tony for the rainout.   C'mon, man, let's go to the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Naw"? There's ice skaters coming!   You ever made love to an ice skater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the dozen. Holiday on Ice, Ice  Capades, Ice Follies -- (beat) I'm through with one night stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're through with one night stands?!   What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanta play everyday despite  small nagging injuries -- and go  home to a woman who appreciates how  full of crap I truly am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're weird, man -- I want a ice  skater real bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I get laid, you won't tell Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE LOOKS AT HIM STRANGELY -- And hurries to the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GUYS ARE GROOMING TO EXCESS -- Still blow drying and  preening for each other. A knock at the door. THEY QUICKLY GET "CASUAL" and lounge seductively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's them, it's them! Be casual. (calling out) Come in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DOOR OPENS -- It's Nuke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys, pa--rty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and be cool, man. Like Mickey  there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICKEY "LOUNGES" WITH A DRINK and a cigaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanta make it to the Show, Rock,  you gotta learn how to "lounge".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE LEANS ON THE BAR with an elbow, striking his version a "lounging" pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EIGHT ICE SKATERS STAND IN THE DOORWAY -- Ready to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pa--rty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POP THE CORK ON THE SEVEN DOLLAR CHAMPAGNE -- And party..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WIVES AND SOME GIRLFRIENDS WATCH "DYNASTY" on Annie's television. Annie hosts, filling their drink glasses, ser popcorn, and largely staying in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think your husband plays around  on the road trips?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. Well... God... do we have to  talk about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not... it's just that once I  asked Mickey if he was faithful to  me on the road trips and he said "in  his heart he was faithful". (beat) What the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means he's unfaithful -- but only  a man would put it in those words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BABY CRIES -- Tommy's Wife lifts a baby from the couch, begins rocking It.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Players are dancing, drinking, hustling the ice skaters, music is up, the party swinging, when: SKIP ENTERS -- He's steaming and slightly drunk. Larry is with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got one word to say to  everybody -- shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE PLAYERS AND ICE SKATERS freeze in mid-party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke -- get everybody in here. Hundred  dollar fine anybody's not here in  five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE POUNDS ON DOORS in a hurry. -- P.O.V. IN FIRST DOOR -- Jimmy is on his knees at the b bare chested, praying with an open Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your holy ass in Room 401.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hustles to the next door, and pounds madly. -- P.O.V. IN SECOND DOOR -- TWO NAKED WOMEN with Jose and Tony, nearly nude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred dollar fine if you're not in  #401 in five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred dollars?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSE AND TONY LOOK AT THE TWO WOMEN -- It's a lot of mone in Class AAA ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ. Sorry ladies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSE AND TONY HURRY OUT in their shorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to hell! You're in last place  anyway!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND NUKE HURRIES DOWN THE HALL -- Pounding on each door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH EATING ALONE -- Peacefully. Nuke arrives excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash! Skip wants everybody in #401  for a team meeting. Hundred buck  fine if ya don't show!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH PULLS OUT THE HUNDRED DOLLAR BILL and hands it to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Party without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God -- what a Big League move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE TAKES THE MONEY and hurries back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 PLAYERS AND 8 ICE SKATERS -- Some of the players Nuke  rounded up are partially dressed. Skip spots the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're ice skaters. Can we go now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I want you to hear my philosophy.   It'll do you some good (beat) Here it is. This is a simple game.   You throw the ball, you hit the ball,  you catch the ball. You got that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you lovely creatures aware that  you are about to compromise yourselves  with a buncha bums who are -- (to Larry) -- what are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight and twenty-four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight and twenty-four! How'd we ever  win 8 games?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, guys -- I'm a man, I got needs  too.  I understand this party --  but... (beat) sex is the one thing you can get  further behind in and catch up faster  than anything I know. (beat) There's a baseball lesson in there  somewhere. (looking around) Where's Crash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE STEPS FORWARD -- Hands Skip the hundred dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can't make it. Here's his fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw Christ, he don't have to come.   He's hitting .350.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think that's a double  standard -- we're here and he ain't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in a double standard for  guys hitting .350. (beat) Look, men -- you got a choice. You  wanta be roasting your nuts off for  Midas Muffler welding exhaust pipes  up the assholes of Cadillacs... or -- (beat) You wanta be sitting in the Caddy  while some other guy's crawling around  in a monkey suit with a blow torch? (beat) There's only two places you can be  in life -- in the Caddy or under it. (nearly pleading) These are the best years of your  lives. These are the glamor days. (beat) It don't got any better than this. (threatening, tough) But... if this club don't start  winning soon, there's gonna be changes  made!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON TELEVISION -- "DYNASTY" drones on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully) Deke was a great player in high  school. I thought held go right to  the Major Leagues -- I was gonna be  a Big League wife. (beat) Pass the Pampers, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva guy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Crash flips off the T.V. with the remote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you think of a pitcher  who wore women's panties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he had a good breaking ball, I'd  respect the shit outta him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash turns off the light. CLOSE ON NUKE -- A bit of light spill on his face. Eyes o A long ways from sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON NUKE'S FACE -- He takes his cap off, wipes his b He's pitching. Everything in SLO-MO. FANS IN THE BALLPARK LAUGH at Nuke, mocking his. EXTREME CLOSE UP ON NUKE'S EYES -- Frightened. SLOW FULLBACK ON NUKE -- HE'S STARK NAKED save for his ca and glove. Everyone else is clothed. NUKE WINDS AND PITCHES in the nude. SLO-MO... and as the  batter cranks up to take a vicious swing --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON NUKE'S FACE -- He awakes with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH LEANS OVER and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, it's okay... you're  dreaming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH HELPS NUKE back to consciousness. Nuke shakes his h trying to wake up. Crash is almost tender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was playing naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know -- I have that dream  all the time. We're almost home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bus continues across the Carolina landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team bus pulls into a deserted parking lot. A few of players' cars are parked. Some of the wives and girlfrien And Annie. THE PLAYERS SHUFFLE OFF the bus. Tired and beat. CLOSE ON NUKE -- He looks worse than the rest. He sees An and waves. She's waiting next to her old Volvo.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREETS OF DURHAM MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: ANNIE'S VOLVO PULLS OUT -- She drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie is up -- Nuke is down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God I'm tired. What a trip I was  lousy. I was worse than lousy.   Everytime I pitched -- it was like  throwing gasoline on a fire. Kaboom.   I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this "I, I, I" stuff? You  only talk about yourself? Aren't you  glad to see me? Don't I look nice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. You look great. I'm totally  exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Total exhaustion can be  spiritually fabulous. (beat) Let's play catch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flowers and birdfeeders everywhere. And, 60 feet away in  complete, oversized catcher's gear -- JACKSON IN A CATCHER'S CROUCH -- Nuke stares, in his stre clothes, but now with a glove and ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hum, babe, hum, babe, fire it in  here, hum babe--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not necessary, Jackson -- (beat) Okay, Nuke, now lean in for the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does. Jackson flashes some ridiculous signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This in ridiculous. I'm a pro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do what I say. Now, which nostril  are you breathing through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which nostril am I breathing through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie puts her hand under his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The right nostril. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My right nostril?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two important psychic  conduits called the "pingala" and  the "ida". The pingala starts with  the left testicle (or left ovary of  the female) and ends at the right  nostril.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches his left nut through his pants in a matter of fact manner. He stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ida originates at the right  testicle (or ovary) and terminates  at the left nostril.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really beat. I need some serious  "z's" --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pingala is the nostril used for  throwing a baseball. (beat) And if you discover before a game  you're in the wrong nostril, it's  easy to switch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Switch nostrils?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Okay, fire a couple in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE TOSSES AN EASY PITCH to Jackson. Annie's incensed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're patronizing me! I will not be  patronized --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I throw too hard I'll hurt the  kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's handled a lotta pitchers whose  records were better than one and  six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke gets a little steamed. He feels his nostril, winds, fires a medium speed fastball to Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit angry) How was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the God damn ball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS UP and fires a pitch to Jackson. Alas -- THE BALL SAILS THROUGH A WINDOW -- Crashing glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically) How ya like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much better. Your delivery was fully  integrated because you weren't  thinking about it 'cause you were  pissed off at me. (beat) This is progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke smiles and gives in. And reaches for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give up. Let's go inside, make  love, and fall asleep till it's time  to go to the ballpark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his hand and leads him up to the back porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or... (taking his hand) ...We could just take that sexual  energy and save it for a few hours  and re-channel it into your pitching  tonight. (shouting) C'mon, Jackson, I've got some  lemonade!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackson runs over in full gear to join them. SITTING ON THE BACK PORCH -- A pitcher of lemonade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't keep up with you. First you  say sex is gonna make me a better  pitcher -- now no sex is gonna do  it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY NUKE'S FACE IS FILLED WITH ALARM -- He points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- P.O.V. A CARDBOARD BOX ON A TABLE NEARBY -- Scrawled i larged letters on the side are the words "MAX PATKIN".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter of factly) That's Max. His ashes anyway. He  left no kin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke stares, unsettled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God... I think I'm gonna be sick --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh don't be silly. Death is nothing  to be scared of. It's just another  way of living. It's just a fresh  start -- kinda like spring training.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke thinks about this carefully. Looks at the ashes, at  Annie, and at Jackson, in full gear, mask on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death is like spring training?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And so is birth. Now look me in  the eyes, Nuke -- (sweetly accusing him) You haven't been wearing my panties,  have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON NUKE -- Utterly bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE PULLS HIS JOCKSTRAP ON over the red panties. Crash notices the panties, and snaps the waistband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot. Very hot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke looks around nervously, continues dressing quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie says her panties will keep one  side of my brain occupied while I'm  on the mound, thus keeping my brain  slightly off center, which is where  it should be for artists and pitchers.  She also said I should throw whatever  pitches you call for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Deke spots Nuke's panties.

dialogues.text: SEVERAL PLAYERS GATHER AROUND -- Wolf whistles aimed at N as the players are dressing into their uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie says there's no such thing as  straight and gay. We're all sexual  creatures to start with, and we get  formed into certain roles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe that?

dialogues.text: When I'm one and six I'll believe  anything. (as they dress) Annie also says that God is a woman.   You believe that, Crash, you think  God's a lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lord God is tri-une -- Father,  Son, and Holy Ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father and Son. Awright!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deke turns to Crash, full of despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! This is a damn noisy  clubhouse for a team that's lost 15  straight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Skip takes off his cap -- instantly sincere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patkin was a tribute to baseball...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACK GOSPEL GROUP at a mike at home plate, singing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) I come to the garden alone, When the  dew is still on the roses, And the  voice I hear, whispering in my ear,.   The Son of God discloses --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
