dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE ON THE MOUND -- PICKS UP the rosin bag, and paces. A small crowd. A batter steps in to hit. Nuke looks in for sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, these panties feel great. That  don't make me queer, right? Right.   Whoo. (reads the sign) Breaking ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS AND DELIVERS -- Breaking ball for a strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't queer. I know I ain't... (reads the sign) Fastball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS AND DELIVERS -- Fastball for a strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE'S BOX SEAT IN THE STANDS -- She charts pitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninety-three miles an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks wonderful, Jackson...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE ON THE MOUND -- He looks in for the sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fastball again? Why's he want the  heat -- I just threw heat. Don't  think, Meat -- give 'em the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS AND DELIVERS -- An eye-popping fastball. The b swings and misses. Strike three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE DUGOUT -- SKIP AND LARRY LOOK AT EACH other warily

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus -- what's got into Nuke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard he's wearing women's underwear --  and he's breathing through his pingala  nostril.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.O.V. NUKES FASTBALL SHATTERS A BAT -- THE HITTER hits a weak roller to third for the second out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO THE MOUND -- Nuke is pumped up. Paces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, Annie's got a great ass... How  come her panties fit me? That's one  of the mysteries of sex I guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS AND DELIVERS A VICIOUS CURVEBALL -- A check sw dribbler to first for the third out. And the players run  into the dugout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE PUTS ON HIS WARM UP JACKET and sits down next to Cra who's taking off his gear, readying to hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was great, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your fastball was up and your  curveball was hanging -- in the Show  they woulda ripped you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you let me enjoy the moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment's over. (rising to get a bat) If this guy starts me off with a  breaking ball, I'm going downtown --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH SMILES in his disarming way, and grabs a bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash kneels, rubbing the bat handle with pine tar. He st the pitcher working the first two hitters. CRASH RISES and heads to the plate. CRASH STEPS INTO THE BOX -- Digs in.

dialogues.text: I dare you to throw me the hammer --  you ain't that stupid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH'S P.O.V. IN SLOW-MOTION -- The pitcher winds and  delivers. And as the ball leaves the pitcher's hand--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breaking ball -- you fool!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH UNLOADS ON THE PITCH -- Crushing a home run deep ov the left field wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEDDY THE RADIO ANNOUNCER is wary about these events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-nothing Bulls in the second --  first time the Bulls have been ahead  in weeks, eh Whitey -- (beat) Let's see if the real Nuke LaLoosh  will show up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE FIRES THREE QUICK PITCHES for another strike out. Cu ball, fast ball, curve ball. Overpowering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SKIP AND LARRY IN THE DUGOUT -- Skip looks at Larry as if say "What's happening?" Larry just shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO THE FIELD -- Nuke's next pitch. THE NEXT BATTER POPS UP -- Crash circles into foul ground make the catch, whipping the ball around the infield. AND CRASH GOES TO THE MOUND for a visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm cruisin', man -- what're  you doing out here?!

dialogues.text: Why?! I'm finally throwin' the damn  thing where I want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH RETURNS TO THE PLATE -- Flashes a sign.

dialogues.text: THE PRESS BOX Teddy's getting worked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a staggering start by LaLoosh --  he's thrown 5 cuts on 9 pitches, all  of them strikes -- he's got pin point  control here tonight, Bull fans...  here's the pitch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE'S NEXT DELIVERY -- A wild ass rocket thirty feet off line. The BULL MASCOT DIVES for cover. THE BATTER STEPS OUT OF THE BOX nervously, muttering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy's crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. Next one might be at your head.  Hell if I know where the damn thing's  going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON NUKE -- Smiles. Winds. Delivers. A change up. THE BATTER SWINGS TERRIBLY OFF STRIDE -- Strike three. Cr whips the ball around the infield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- top of the ninth, two outs, one  out away from a stunning two hit  shutout for LaLoosh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE ON THE MOUND -- Bearing down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bear down, Meat, don't let up. You  own these guys. Dad'll love a  shutout...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.O.V. CRASH FLASHES THE SIGN -- Nuke doesn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no -- this guy's looking for  heat -- lemme give him the deuce --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE SHAKES OFF THE SIGN Cocky, full of himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE AND JACKSON in her box seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no -- he's shaking off the sign,  Jackson. Big mistake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This son of a bitch is throwing a  two hit shutout and he's shaking me  off?! (to batter and umpire) Hey Charlie, here comes the deuce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS AND DELIVERS -- A hanging curveball. The batte takes an ungodly cut, and BLASTS a long home. THE BATTER STANDS AT THE PLATE watching the blast... unti CRASH SHOVES HIM toward first with a sneer. For a moment looks like there'll be a fight -- but the hitter backs of and takes the home run trot as: NUKE STARES AT THE OUTFIELD WALL as the batter circles th bases. Crash walks to the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told him I was throwing a deuce,  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. He really crushed that dinger,  didn't he. Musta gone 450 feet...  damn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE HOLDS OUT HIS GLOVE -- Says nothing. Crash puts a ne ball in the glove. Returns to the plate. NUKE GETS THE SIGN -- Winds. Delivers. Batter hits a weak one hopper back to the mound. Game's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A raucous celebration of the victory. Booze flows. And we begin hearing the familiar sounds of Piaf...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE COMES OUT OF THE BATHROOM -- Dressed in a long, flo nightgown, elegant and old fashioned. She looks fabulous, PRESENTING HERSELF to Nuke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'know, Annie, I been thinking if it  works for one game, maybe it'll work  for a whole buncha games.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathing through your pingala always  works, honey --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that. I mean the re-channeling  of my sexual energy. (beat) Maybe we shouldn't make love for  awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't go overboard, I look  incredibly hot, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She strikes a pose. She does look hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what it feels like to throw  a three hitter? (nervously, with  resolve) We better not fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just till I lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebby Calvin "Nuke" LaLoosh --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts toward him -- and Nuke flees. Out the door, in the night. Annie slumps in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE SITS IN BED ALONE -- Lights a cigarette. A puzzled  expression -- things have got out of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke was so encouraged that he took  a vow to not have sex until they  lost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie reaches over, opens a drawer in her nightstand, and pulls out her baseball glove. She cradles it fondly in he lap, puts it on, pounds it gently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'see a ballplayer on a streak  considers himself touched with magic  and he'll do anything to keep from  breaking the spell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE NEATLY UNFOLDS THE RED PANTIES in his locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact the whole team started making  religious connections and everybody  got hot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSE BLESSES THE BATS with a chicken bone cross. JIMMY READS THE BIBLE and prays alone in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PLAYERS TAKING GROUND BALLS and batting practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figured Nuke would win a couple,  then lose, and things would get back  to normal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PLAYERS PLAYING "FLIP" PEPPER like kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it didn't happen like that...  and for one extraordinary June and  July, the Durham Bulls, for whatever  perverse reason, began playing  baseball with joy and verve and poetry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE WARMING UP in the bullpen, listening to Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two sides of my own brain were  all jumbled up and cross-wired...   while one side was being neglected,  the other was in paradise watching  our Bulls play like Big Leaguers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICKEY RIPS A TRIPLE UP THE ALLEY -- Slides into third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We swept a four game series with  Kingston, back to back doubleheaders  with Winston-Salem, and kicked the  holy shit out of Greensboro in a  three game series...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEVERAL PLAYERS SIGNING AUTOGRAPHS at a local mall. A lin of kids to meet them. A banner -- MEET YOUR BULLS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were in demand all over town --  and Crash, who kept hitting dingers,  was approaching the minor league  record... though I told nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH BLASTS ANOTHER HOME RUN -- Another win. JULY 4 PROMOTION -- LARRY, DEKE, TOMMY, AND JOSE dressed the "Spirit of 176 Drum and Fife Corps" at home plate,  surrounded by a Boy Scout Troop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After sweeping a July 4 doubleheader,  the Durham Bulls were tied for first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WIVES, THE GROUPIES, AND MILLIE WAIT for the players  outside the clubhouse following a game. ANNIE SITS ALONE IN HER BOX SEAT as the stadium empties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But beautiful as the winning streak  was, I was getting damn lonely. (beat) Something had to be done. I needed a  man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds of Diana Ross and the Supremes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARRY, DEKE, TOMMY AND MICKEY as the Supremes, singing "S in the Name of Love" at the front of the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love winning, Crash, you hear me?   I love it. Teach me everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time you started working on  your interviews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I gotta do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learn your clichГ©s. Study them. Know  them. They're your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash hands Nuke a small pad and pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write this down. (beat) "We gotta play 'em one day at a time."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. That's the point. (beat) "I'm just happy to be here and hope  I can help the ballclub."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Write, write -- "I just wanta give  It my best shot and, Good Lord  willing, things'll work out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE STARTS WRITING them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Good Lord willing, things'll  work out."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. So how's Annie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke looks up from his clichГ©s, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's getting steamed 'cause I'm  still re-channeling my sexual energy --  maybe I should cave in and sleep  with her once just to calm her down.   What'ya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You outta your mind? If you give in  now you might start losing. (beat) Never fuck with a winning streak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke nods seriously, listening to the master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BUS PULLS IN -- Wives and girlfriends are waiting. The players get off, greet their women. ANNIE GREETS NUKE -- They head for her Volvo.. JIMMY STARTS ACROSS THE LOT on foot, dragging his luggage when Millie pulls up in her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Jimmy. Want a ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Have you accepted Jesus Christ as  your personal savior?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I give you my testimony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can do anything you want. (a tiny grin) Hop in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIMMY NERVOUSLY GETS IN WITH MILLIE They roar away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE SITS AT THE TABLE -- He's just finished eating. Annie circles him. A pot of soup on the stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so proud of you and all the guys.   Want some more soup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it was great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout a back rub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's okay. All I need's a little  nap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tuck you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) You can't seduce me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna try to seduce you,  sweetie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE STRETCHES OUT HER LEG and lays it an the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls back her skirt slightly, exposing her garter sn attached to her stockings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure we could work on some  fundamentals even if we don't make  love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She strokes her leg. Nuke stares fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fundamentals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. (beat) Unsnap my stockings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke squirms, then reaches for her garter snaps. And stop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash once called a woman's, uh --  pussy -- y'know how the hair kinda  makes a "V" shape? --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well -- he calls it the Bermuda  Triangle. He said a man can get lost  in there and never be heard from  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a nasty thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't mean it nasty. He said  that gettin' lost and disappearing  from the face of the earth was  sometimes a good thing to do --  especially like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... (beat) Crash is a very smart man. Now c'mon,  honey, give it a try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE REACHES FOR THE GARTER SNAPS with two hands. He fumb groping awkwardly. Annie stops him gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch... one hand --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WITH A SINGLE HAND ANNIE FLICKS each snap. Flick, flick,  flick. Magic. The snaps open effortlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE RE-SNAPS THEM QUICKLY, offering her leg to Nuke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE TRIES AGAIN -- One handed. Awkwardly again, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighing sexually) Mmmmmmm... oh yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUT NUKE LEAPS TO HIS FEET -- Reacting vigorously, nervou desperately. The soup crashes on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! You're playing with my mind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to play with your body!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it -- you're seducing me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm seducing you for  Godsakes, and I'm doing a damn poor  job of it -- (beat) Aren't I pretty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're real cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cute?! I hate cute! Baby ducks are  cute! I wanta be exotic and  mysterious!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're exotic and mysterious and  cute -- that's why I better leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke starts to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke! You got things all wrong!  There's no relation between sex and  baseball. Ask Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said if I gave in to you I'd start  losing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be back when we lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE HURRIES OUT THE DOOR -- Annie just stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A run of the mill cheap modern motel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH WORKS ON HIS SWING in front of a mirror. A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE ENTERS the room. Crash stays with his stance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash... I want you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke won't go to bed with you, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's confused --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think I'm pretty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash puts down the bat, and looks directly at her. As he does he picks up two spring loaded hand exercisers and be pumping them an he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gorgeous, God damn it! From  the moment I first saw you I knew I  had to have you. I had to have you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think of you and the "boy" all the  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't make love to me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he's right! A ballplayer on a  streak has to respect the streak.  They don't happen very often. (beat) You know how hard this game is? If  you believe you're playing well  because you're getting laid or because  you're not getting laid or because  you wore red silk panties -- then  you are! (beat) And I still think Thomas Pynchon is  full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you desperately!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash can hardly keep up. So he slows her down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? Do you have a job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I teach part time at the Junior  College. What if I told you I was  through with Nuke? He learned his  lessons quickly and left me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you wanta teach me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't imagine there's much I could  teach you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash, I get wet just thinking about  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted an  "uncomplicated" boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready for a complicated man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and as soon as we lose a game,  he'll be back in your arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said when I think about you, I get  wet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, I think you should leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie launches into a tirade without orchestration or sel awareness. She's frustrated, confused, angry and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn you -- what is happening?  Is there no man who'll have me? (beat) This is the weirdest season I ever  saw -- the Durham Bulls can't lose  and I can't get laid!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie slides against the wall down to the floor. Tears fl Her makeup runs. Her eyes are red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakily) I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash gingerly helps her to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE AND CRASH SIT IN THE CORNER of the empty bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why baseball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) I was raised in a Baptist church got  dipped in the water when I was 5 --  born again before kindergarten... by  the time I was 10 I knew it was  bullshit and at 15 I ran away from  home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHE SMILES at the most painful memories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pregnant, had an abortion, got  pregnant again, had an abortion  again... gave up men. Tried women.  Missed men. My mother died. (beat) I bought a car for $200 and drove to  Ft. Lauderdale to bury her. (beat) And after we'd sung some hymns in  some wretched Florida funeral home,  I went outside and something happened --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her tone becomes wistful, nostalgic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The smell of cut grass in the warm  March air overwhelmed me and I heard  a noise -- (makes the sound)) -- tok, tok, tok -- and some men  shouting... then tok, tok, tok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash smiles slightly. He knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I crossed the street -- it was the  New York Yankees spring training  field -- tok, tok, tok, was the sound  of a ball hitting a bat -- and I sat  in the warm bleachers to think about  my mother... (beat) And I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thurman Munson. (beat) He was covered with dirt and he was  fighting with everybody -- it was  beautiful... (beat) And he called the ump a cocksucker  and got thrown out of the game even  though it was an exhibition! (beat) So I stayed in the bleachers all  spring and gradually came to  understand what's so great about  baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so great about baseball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you know where home plate is,  then you know where 1st base is, and  2nd, and everything else -- 'cause  they're always in the same place in  relation to home. (beat) Don't you see? If you know where  home plate is, then you know where  everything else in the universe is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I'd go that far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true, It's true! (beat, down) Least it used to be true. It ain't  possible that baseball's not enough  anymore, is it, Crash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna be waking up next to  20 year old ballplayers when you're  60?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I used to think that wasn't  the worst thing in the world to look  forward to. Lately I'm not so sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Whatta you mean "why not"? Are you  gonna play forever?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Crash can answer -- SUDDENLY A VOICE interrupts. They both turn to see: MILLIE EXCITEDLY DRAGGING JIMMY into the nearly empty bar She leads him by the hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, Annie! There she is -- we've  been looking all over for ya. Hi  Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLIE LEADS JIMMY right up to their table. And as they h hands. Jimmy stands there shyly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well tell 'em, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) We're getting married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLIE STICKS OUT HER LEFT HAND Displays a huge ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Omigawd, honey, I'm so happy for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a virgin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy squirms defensively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah... (to Annie and Crash) I guess that probably seems pretty  corny to people like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Jimmy, honey, I think it sounds  wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie, will you be the bride's maid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GAME IN PROGRESS -- Nuke on the mound. NUKE WINDS AND DELIVERS -- Very high. Ball three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSIDE THE DUGOUT -- Skip and Larry spitting tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke's overthrowing tonight, he don't  look loose. Anything bothering him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said his chakras were jammed and  he was breathing out of the wrong  nostril.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spitting tobacco) Okay...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO THE MOUND
dialogues.text: NUKE WINDS AND DELIVERS AGAIN -- Very high. Ball four. CRASH IS QUICKLY to the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm nervous -- my old man's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE MOTIONS -- They both look. -- P.O.V.  NUKE'S FATHER SITTING in a special box seat. T man is 45, and is operating a home video camera taking  pictures of his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, he's just your father, man --  he's as full of shit as anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOMMY AND DEKE JOIN THEM at the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You breathing through the wrong  fucking nostril again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you guys hear Jimmy and Millie  are engaged?! Wait'll I tell him  she's gone down on half the Carolina  League --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (threatening) Anybody says anything bad about  Millie, I'll break his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, guys, I got a game to pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSE THE FIRST BASEMAN JOINS THEM ALL at the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't throw anything to me -- my  girlfriend put a curse on my glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the curse off the son of a  bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you got to cut the head off a  live rooster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICKEY JOINS THE CROWD from third base.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, man, this umpire's a  God damn racist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.O.V.  THE UMPIRE -- He's black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DUGOUT -- SKIP AND LARRY watch the growing meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a damn convention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE MOUND -- Larry joins the convention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke's scared cause his nostrils are  jammed and his old man's here, we  need a live rooster to take the curse  off Jose's glove, and nobody knows  what to get Jimmy and Millie for  their wedding present -- there's a  whole lotta shit we're trying to  deal with --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I thought there was a problem.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANNIE'S HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: ANNIE IS HELPING MILLIE make her WEDDING DRESS. The game can be heard on the radio in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be at the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no -- I'm fine. Millie, how much  time did you and Jimmy spend together  before he proposed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie holds the dress up to Millie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five hours. We both just know. (studying the dress) Do you think I deserve to wear white?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all deserve to wear white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOTH WOMEN TURN THEIR HEADS to the radio to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...line drive up the alley's gonna  score at least two, here comes the  relay --

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DURHAM BALLPARK THE GAME NIGHT
dialogues.text: CRASH FLIPS HIS MASK -- A runner rounds third heading for home. Here comes the throw, on a line. It hits once on th infield grass, takes a long hop -- AS THE RUNNER BARRELS TOWARD THE PLATE -- Crash takes the throw. THE RUNNER SLIDES -- Crash blocks the plate. A cloud of d A close play. THE UMPIRE SIGNALS "SAFE" -- And Crash flips out. In a se he is nose to nose with the UMPIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got him on the knee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn It, Jack, he still ain't  touched the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEIR FACES ARE INCHES APART -- Screaming face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bump me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a cocksucking call!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you call me a cocksucker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I said It was a cock-sucking  call and you can't run me for that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You missed the tag!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You spit on me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't spit on you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're in the wrong business, Jack --  you're Sears-Roebuck material!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're close, Crash, you want me to  run you? I'll run you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to call you a cocksucker?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try it! Go ahead. Call me a  cocksucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beg me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me a cocksucker and you're outta  here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beg me again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me a cocksucker and you're outta  here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a cocksucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're outta here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE UMP THEATRICALLY THROWS CRASH out of the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE AND MILLIE STARE at the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I've never seen Crash so angry  and frankly, Bull fans, he used a  certain word that's a "no-no" with  umpires...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash musta called the guy a  cocksucker

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, he's so romantic...

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE SHOWERS NIGHT
dialogues.text: CRASH STANDS AGAINST the water, letting it stream across  him. He raises a can of beer to his lips, drinks it slowl in the shower. As the water runs over Crash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Crash got throwed out, the game  got out of hand... (beat) ...Jose made three errors with his  cursed mitt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSE BOOTS A GROUND BALL -- A runner scores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke never quite got in the groove  though he didn't pitch bad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE JUST MISSES WITH A PITCH -- Ball four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the winning streak came to an  end with a 3-2 loss... (beat) The good news was that a man was  about to come calling... the bad  news was -- it was the wrong guy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANNIE'S LIVING ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: AS PIAF PLAYS on the stereo -- A knock at the door. ANNIE GOES TO THE DOOR -- Then refuses to answer it at fi She hides in a corner. Bites her fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie! You gotta be in there -- I  can hear that crazy Mexican singer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie smiles slightly, and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door fully. Nuke's father stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like you to meet my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Oh -- won't YOU come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS THEY ENTER -- She leads them into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebby's told me a lot about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh oh... (beat) Can I offer you some coffee?

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: She puts a pot of water with a swirl of graciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Ebby tells me you're a very  spiritual woman. He tells me you've  taught him a lot about discipline  and self-control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie and Nuke exchange glances. Nuke smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good student.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were worried that Ebby might get  involved with the wrong crowd in  professional baseball -- we're so  pleased, he met a Christian woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise the Lord, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Piaf record begins skipping in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my -- I better fix that. Ebby  will you help me? I'm no good with  mechanical things

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke picks up his cue and follows her to:

dialogues.speaker: THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Annie fixes the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't dump my old man but maybe  later I can sneak away from him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starting to understand what you're  teaching me. I mean the panties and  the nostrils and all that shit... I  mean I'm getting it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So am I. Nuke, honey, we need to  talk --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke gets very aggressive and playful, pinning her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw hell, let's have a quickie right  here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but you're father's in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash says I gotta quit worrying  about him -- c'mon, honey, we got a  lotta catching up to do --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pins her to the wall, she squirms away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke -- we do need to talk!

dialogues.speaker: BACK IN THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Nuke's father is studying pictures on Annie's wall. CLOSE ON A HELMUT NEWTON PHOTO -- A nude woman, two afgha and a toilet.

dialogues.speaker: A PHOTO OF SWAMI PRABHAVANANDA YOGANDA
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A POSTER OF A MARIJUANA LEAF with the inscriptio "Better Living Through Mexican Agriculture". Nuke's father is a bit unsettled by all this, when: The phone rings. ANNIE SWEEPS BACK into the kitchen -- saved by the bell - to answer the phone. Nuke trails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hello? Skip? Yeah, as a matter of  fact, he is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands the phone to Nuke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Skip, for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Skip, it's me. (several beats) Jeez... Jeez... God... Jeez...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke hangs up the phone. Looks at Annie and his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the Show. (beat) They're sending me up to finish out  the season with the Big Club. I'm  going to the Show!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE'S FATHER LEAPS TO HIS FEET and embraces his son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have a quick word of prayer,  right here, to thank the Lord for  all this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh let's not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta leave first thing in the  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I possibly thank you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He embraces her rather formally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just pitch well and do good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke hustles his father out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, I will -- C'mon, Dad, I'll  dump you off. I gotta find Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they exit, Nuke's father turns to Annie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself) She will, Mr. LaLoosh, she will...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE SITS DOWN in a kitchen chair. An enormous sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke knocks on Crash's door. Nobody home. Tony is arrivin with his GROUPIE GIRLFRIEND to the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash ain't there. He never gets  back till four or five --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where does he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd rather not say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They called me up to the Show and I  wanta tell Crash goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY COMES OVER AND GIVES NUKE a heartfelt "five".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn, that's great! Jesus! (beat) Listen, Crash don't like anybody to  know it but -- (beat) Most nights he goes down to, you  know, down to Niggertown. To  Sandy's... the whorehouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to a whorehouse every night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell him I told you -- he'd  break my neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON NUKE -- Disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CAB MOVES SLOWLY through a poor neighborhood. Stops at: AN OLD HOUSE -- Decades of ad hoc add-ons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Sandy's. Keep your extra cash  In your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE GETS OUT and goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE KNOCKS AT THE DOOR -- A small barred window opens. A face appears -- a TOUGH BLACK, SANDY, 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'you want, kid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who ain't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for Crash Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Nuke LaLoosh. With the Bulls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying him) Your breaking ball's getting better  but ya need a change up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Nuke enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE ENTERS TENTATIVELY -- Another world. Grim. Sleazy. The Doorman leads him down a hallway full of doors. A BLA PROSTITUTE enters a room with a HUGE REDNECK. As they go  down the hallway, and as they do: We begin hearing singing -- raucous, soulful, drunk. NUKE STOPS IN A DOORWAY -- Looks into the "waiting room". -- P.O.V.  SEVERAL HOOKERS in various stages of undress, on couches and chairs. Bored, smoking, ancient. The ONE W HOOKER, a skinny 25 year old, accompanies on a guitar,  struggling to keep up. And a couple HOOKERS are hanging a a piano that -- CRASH IS PLAYING and singing. He doesn't look up. Crash i dressed but barefoot. A cigarette dangles from his mouth he accompanies himself with decent cocktail lounge chords Two Hookers at the piano hum along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing and playing) But when she does get weary -- Try a  little tenderness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE STEPS INTO THE ROOM -- All the Hookers rise in  anticipation of a new customer. Crash keeps playing, neve looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) You know she's waiting, just  anticipating, the things that she'll  never possess... (beat) While she's there waiting -- Try a  little tenderness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke interrupts the instrumental passage:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash. I'm going to the Show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash Ignores him, keeps playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Club's expanding its roster to finish  the season --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. I'm playing. (singing last 8 bars) Oh you won't regret it, young girls  don't forget it, lost in their own  wilderness... (beat) But it's all so easy -- Just try a  little tenderness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Crash plays on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the Show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE GRABS CRASH by the hair and jerks him to his feet. T two men are face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let go of me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE LETS HIM GO and Crash staggers drunkenly against the piano, regaining his balance as: SANDY RUSHES IN WITH A GUN to break it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makin' trouble for you, Mr. Davis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, Sandy, put it down. (drunkenly, to Nuke) Nuke, you know Sandy Grimes? Hit  .367 at Louisville in 155.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hit .371.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hit .371 -- C'mon, Nuke -- you  and me, let's step outside and settle  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settle what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanta fight you, I wanta  thank you. Let's have a drink and  forget this --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn it, you fucking virgin prick --  step outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash drunkenly heads out the back door in his underwear. Nuke reluctantly follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several of the Hookers follow to watch. Crash is drunk an lost. Nuke in control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, we got nothin' to fight about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I a fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you a fuck? (beat) 'Cause you got talent. I got brains.  But you got talent! You're God damn  left arm is worth a million dollars  a year. (drunken insight) All my limbs put together are worth  7 cents a pound -- and that's for  science and dog meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a great catcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over here into the light so I  can kick your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll kick your ass there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash takes a step toward Nuke. Pulls up his bare feet  quickly, stepping on a sharp stone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...God damn... I forgot my fucking  shoes. Honey, go get my shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Hookers goes inside for his shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take you back to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drunken, mad) You know what the difference is  between hitting .250 and hitting  .300? I got it figured out. (beat) Twenty-five hits a year in 500 at  bats is 50 points. Okay? There's 6  months in a season, that's about 25  weeks -- you get one extra flare a  week -- just one -- a gork, a ground  ball with eyes, a dying quail --  just one more dying quail a week and  you're in Yankee Stadium!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE HOOKER FINDS CRASH'S SHOES -- Starts to bring them ou to him when... she notices cash in one of them. The Hooke takes a few bills for herself, and continues out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK IN THE ALLEY -- Crash finishes his tirade as:

dialogues.speaker: THE HOOKER COMES OUT WITH CRASH'S SHOES
dialogues.text: He struggles drunkenly to put them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. You ain't worth thanking --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE STARTS TO WALK AWAY -- Crash fires his one free shoe Nuke hitting him in the back of the head. NUKE WHIRLS -- Comes after Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Meat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH SWINGS WILDLY -- Nuke ducks it and levels Crash wit short right hand. CRASH CRASHES INTO SOME GARBAGE CANS -- Lies there on his back for several beats. Nuke stares. CLOSE ON CRASH -- Blood trickles from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke... tell me something. Did you  hit me with your right or your left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Crash's next line is both drunk and sober and we don't know if he's just being clever or if, somehow, he's staged It all. Maybe even he doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Good. That's terrific...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If ya get in a fight with some  asshole, never hit his with your  pitching hand. Ya might get injured. (smiles) That's another lesson for ya -- now  quit fucking around and help me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH REACHES UP A HAND FOR HELP -- Nuke stares back. AND FINALLY NUKE REACHES DOWN AND HELPS CRASH to his feet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya look like shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men head inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE'S PORSCHE -- The Clubhouse Boy drags Nuke's out to t car and loads the trunk. Annie, Larry and a COUPLE KIDS A DOGS are watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE CLEANS OUT HIS LOCKER -- Filling his travel bag. Crash sits on a stool next to him. Sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been known, on occasion, to  howl at the moon. D'you understand  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will. (beat) Look, Nuke -- these Big League hitters  are gonna light you up like a pin  ball machine for awhile -- don't  worry about it. Be cocky and arrogant  even when you're getting beat. That's  the secret. (beat) You gotta play this game with fear  and arrogance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fear and ignorance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raging) No. Fear and arrogance, you, hayseed,  not ignorance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles calmly) I know. I just like to see you get  all worked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash calms down. Sighs. Nuke nods and picks up his bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knows it's not true) Well, I got Annie all warmed up for  ya... (knows it is true) She's just waiting for you to show  up, y'know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need a crazy woman in my  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you do. (quick beat) Y'know I'm starting to like this  game -- baseball's a helluva good  way to make a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash speaks with quiet passion, from his soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the best, Nuke... the absolute  fucking best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks for everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands, and Nuke heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke -- (Nuke stops) Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too... Meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuke smiles. A little arrogance and fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE TOSSES HIS BAG in the Porsche and motions to Annie. They step away from the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I guess this is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I won't be needing these anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE PULLS ANNIE'S RED PANTIES from his jacket pocket. The frilly, silk lace is tattered. The panties have been  through the mill. She accepts them graciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither will I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm ready for the Show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebby Calvin Nuke LaLoosh -- don't  think too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other awkwardly, sweetly, and: NUKE KISSES ANNIE GENTLY ON THE LIPS -- They hesitate, an Nuke heads for his Porsche. CRASH ARRIVES IN THE DOORWAY to watch. Nuke bids farewell his father and climbs into his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go now, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking I could fly up and  spend a week in the Big Leagues with  you -- help you get comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. If I screw up, I wanta do it  alone. I'll call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be praying for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad -- if my curveball is hanging,  God ain't gonna help me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll pray anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kindly) If it makes you and mom feel better,  go for it. I gotta run --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands, and: CRASH'S P.O.V. -- NUKE ROARS AWAY in his Porsche, leaving trail of dust in the Stadium parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILLIE AND JIMMY'S WEDDING -- A formal wedding on the  pitcher's mound. Millie in white. Jimmy in his uniform. S is the best man, also in uniform, and several players and groupies are the attendants, Annie as the Bride's Maid. Organ music plays the wedding march. JIMMY LIFTS MILLIE'S VEIL and kisses her. The stands are  full of fans. JIMMY LEADS MILLIE DOWN THE "AISLE" towards home plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON SCOREBOARD -- Ninth inning. Durham is leading by score of 1 to 0. Two outs. JIMMY IS PITCHING -- He delivers. The batter rockets a li drive up the alley. A PENINSULA RUNNER races from first,  rounding third, trying to score. A relay. CRASH WAITS AT THE PLATE -- Here comes the runner. Here c the throw. A close play. A terrible collision. Crash goes rolling. The umpire waits -- and in a cloud of dust, Crash holds up the ball. THE CROWD ROARS -- Jimmy jumps victoriously in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air of victory. The mood is up and goofy. Beer cans a squirted at Jimmy, the groom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanta thank everybody and the Lord  for the victory, it's a wonderful  way to celebrate my marriage -- and  I guess we're all back on a winning  streak, he? A few raucous "Fuckin  A's" from the team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Jimmy -- we chipped in and kind  got a little gift for ya of a special  wedding cake from the Durham Bulls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEKE CARRIES OUT AN WEDDING CAKE -- It's X-Rated. The  decorative Bride and Groom are fucking. Jimmy's embarrass but it's all good natured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH COMING OUT OF THE SHOWER -- Toweling off, watching innocent, vulgar fun. He sits down in front of his locker drying his hair, when the CLUBHOUSE BOY approaches:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Crash -- Skip wants to see ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH RISES AND HEADS FOR SKIP'S CUBICLE -- Wearing only towel and his shower shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSIDE SKIP'S OFFICE -- Skip and Larry sit in postgame  routine, checking charts, smoking, half dressed. CRASH ENTERS as he's still drying off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Skip, you wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash, shut the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it hits him. Crash looks at Skip, who looks down at t floor, unwilling to face Crash who then looks at Larry, w also looks away nervously. CRASH SHUTS THE DOOR -- The party rages beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartfelt) This is the toughest job a manager  has...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON CRASH -- He's been in the game too long to be  surprised; nonetheless, he's surprised. And hurt. His sto is professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The organization wants to make a  change... now that Nuke's gone they  wanta bring up some young catcher...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some kid hittin' .300 in Lynchburg...  probably a bust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put in a word for you with the  organization -- told 'em I thought  you'd make a fine minor league manager  someday... Might be an opening at  Salem next year --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE UP ON CRASH -- His eyes are moist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva year, Crash -- you know how  it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Crash stands there nearly nude. He just nods slightly. Wi rancor or bitterness, he turns and re-enters the raucous  locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH WALKS THE STREETS ALONE -- Crash stops in front of window and takes his batting stroke, studying the reflect

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. CHEAP BAR IN DOWNTOWN DURHAM
dialogues.text: CRASH DRINKING ALONE at the end of a bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH WANDERS ALONG into the residential neighborhoods. HE STARTS ACROSS A QUIET INTERSECTION Stops. Looks at the street signs. He CHANGES DIRECTION, walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The windows glow. After midnight. CRASH STARES AT THE HOUSE -- Hesitates, then walks up the porch stairs. Knocks at the door. Moments later: ANNIE OPENS THE DOOR -- She looks beautiful. Almost as if she was expecting him. At first, silence. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got released.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHE OPENS THE DOOR -- Crash enters Annie's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE PUTS ON her favorite Piaf record. ANNIE POURS A DRINK for both of them. CRASH PUTS A HAND ON HER HIP -- Annie closes her eyes, a  tiny gasp. He kisses her forehead. She kisses his neck. A tiny smile from Crash. The same from Annie. SHE KISSES HIM on the corner of his mouth. Her hand finds the back of his head and she runs her fingers through his hair. CRASH RESPONDS -- They kiss slowly, deeply.  As -- HIS HAND ON HER HIP PULLS UP HER SKIRT -- By degrees, the skirt is raised up her stocking covered leg. At last expo the beloved BLACK GARTER SNAPS -- Crash's hand expertly h up the skirt and effortlessly UNSNAPS THE GARTER with a  minimum of effort. FLICK, FLICK, FLICK -- The garter snaps are free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BEDROOM -- Crash carries Annie to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE'S FOOT KICKS OVER A LAMP onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE'S BLOUSE FRONT -- Flick, flick, flick. Crash unbutt it with one hand in seconds. Even Annie is startled with speed and ease of Crash's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HER HAND SLIDES UNDER THE WAISTBAND of his underwear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIS HAND SLIDES UP UNDER HER panties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FULL EMBRACE ON THE EDGE OF THE BED -- Remnants of clot cover parts of their bodies.  They tumble out of control the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE'S HAND GRABS ONTO A DRESSER LEG -- A carved oak ant her hand holds on tight and shakes the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DRESSER TOP SHAKES -- Makeup bottles and pictures and dozens of Annie's special things rattle and fall

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE'S READ RESTS ON CRASH'S STOMACH -- Post coital, the lie on the floor blissfully as Piaf finishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE CHANGES THE RECORD to Hank Williams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE KITCHEN -- ANNIE AND CRASH eat an after mid after sex snack. Crash eats a bowl of Wheaties. They each wear one her robes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie sits, munching a carrot and rolling a joint of mari she keeps in a Victorian jewel box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...so you see in a former lifetime  I'm sure that I was Alexandria, the  Czarette of Russia? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come in former lifetimes,  everybody was someone famous? (beat) How come nobody ever says they were  Joe Schmo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't work like that. (stares at him) God, you're gorgeous. Want to dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY KISS AGAIN -- And fall gradually onto the table top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE SITS ON TOP OF CRASH lying on the kitchen table. He stretches out a leg and: KICKS THE BOWL OF CEREAL to the floor. It smashes -- cera milk, cereal go everywhere. As: THEY START MAKING LOVE AGAIN in the glaring kitchen light

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH AND ANNIE DANCE in her living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BEDROOM -- Crash is handcuffed to the bed. He seems  perfectly happy as Annie reads Walt Whitman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...mouth, tongue, lips, teeth, roof  of the mouth, jaws, and the jaw  hinges...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE HANDCUFFED TO THE BED -- Crash reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...wrist and wrist joints, hand,  palm, knuckles, thumb, fore-finger,  finger-joints, finger-nail...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH AT ANNIE'S RECORD COLLECTION -- He thumbs through i quickly, puts on a new record. The Dominoes sing "Sixty Minute Man".  And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BATHROOM -- Candlelight around the bathtub. All we ca make out is two heads, two bodies, sloshing wildly In the dim glow. Water splashes, dowses some candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH AND ANNIE IN BED READING -- Each with a copy of a T Pynchon novel. Crash tosses it aside. And disappears unde the sheets, playing with her as she struggles to keep rea She puts down the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE APPLYING EYE MAKEUP TO CRASH -- Who doesn't resist, seems even amused. He kisses her deeply, slowly. She kiss him back. They fall onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.O.V.  OUT THE KITCHEN WINDOW -- Dawn. A bird chirps. And we hear a record skipping, repeating endlessly. PAN ACROSS THE KITCHEN -- Overturned chairs, spilled and  broken cereal bowls, liquor bottles. PAN ACROSS THE BEDROOM -- A disaster. Clothes scattered a the floor, overturned lamps, the bed lies at a cockeyed a Annie and Crash lie face down -- asleep, utterly spent. CRASH WAKES UP SLOWLY -- Reaches up and pulls his underwe off of a lampshade, pulls them on, and gets slowly out of bed. He staggers across the bedroom floor, stumbling a bi into: THE LIVING ROOM -- He stumbles across the trashed room.   Record album covers, more liquor bottles, pillows, cushio pictures hanging crookedly on the wall. CRASH TAKES THE SKIPPING RECORD off the player and breath a sigh of relief. He sees his pants lying on the floor an pulls them on. CRASH OPENS A DRAWER -- Pulls out a piece of paper and a  pencil. He starts writing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sun streams in. Annie opens her eyes. Rubs them. Reaches  over for Crash. Her hand hits a note. She whirls. He's go Only a note. SHE SITS UP WITH A START and reads the note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crash said he had to get an early  start to drive to Asheville in the  South Atlantic League where he heard  they might need a catcher to finish  out the season...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOOM IN EXTREME CLOSE UP OF NOTE -- "Love, Crash".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH IN HIS CAR heading for Asheville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH KNOCKING ON THE BASEBALL OFFICE DOOR -- Looking for work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH UNLOADING HIS GEAR into yet another locker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE SCRUBBING HER KITCHEN FLOOR -- Down on her hands an knees, picking up the broken cereal bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house smelled like sex for days.  It was wonderful. The only real  cleaning I did was on the kitchen  floor 'cause who likes to walk on  spilt cereal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHE FINDS A BIT OF A JOINT on the floor as she's cleaning She picks it up, sits on the floor under the table, and l the tiny joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The funny thing is, I stopped worrying  about Nuke. Somehow I knew nothing  would stop him. Crash was right -- Nuke had a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NUKE IN STREET CLOTHES IN THE DUGOUT of an empty stadium. 50,000 seats. Slick. Awesome. He's being interviewed by a BIG LEAGUE REPORTER, who has a small tape deck and has st mike in Nuke's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a big leaguer) Y'know, I'm just happy to be here  and hope I can help the ballclub. I  just want to give it my best shot  and good Lord willing, things'll  work out... gotta play 'em one day  at a time, Y'know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BIG LEAGUE REPORTER nods attentively as Nuke knowingl delivers the clichГ©s like a veteran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In sharpest contrast to the Big League stadium, a rickety old wooden grandstand, carved into the pine covered hills CRASH STEPS TO THE PLATE -- In a uniform we've never seen him in, of course. The Asheville Tourists. He picks up so dirt, rubs it on his hands. He's as intense as ever. Stil playing for keeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the plate) C'mon, Meat, throw me that weak ass  shit -- c'mon, bring the heat, bring  it, bring it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH'S P.O.V. -- SLO-MO AS THE PITCHER WINDS AND deliver fastball right down the pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE LIES IN BED READING -- She suddenly jerks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was reading in bed when Crash hit  his 247th home run. I knew the moment  it happened...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH UNLOADS A MONSTROUS HOME RUN deep into the trees. H stands at home plate watching it... like Reggie or the Ba And doesn't move. For several seconds he indulges himself uncharacteristically -- until... THE OPPOSING CATCHER SHOVES HIM toward first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your ass in gear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CRASH SMILES and takes the home run trot slowly. As he he toward first, HE RAISES A CLINCHED FIST for a brief momen a tiny gesture of triumph. And then, routinely, he just  circles the bases. A HUNDRED FANS APPLAUD ROUTINELY as he circles the bases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHE LIGHTS A CANDLE for the home run. Above the candles,  displayed in the shrine, are her RED PANTIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lit a candle for Crash's dinger...  and tried to root the Durham Bulls  home to a pennant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE AND JACKSON OPEN AN UMBRELLA in her familiar place the stadium. Umbrellas go up all around, as: THE RAINS COME -- The players huddle-in the dugouts. IN THE DUGOUT Skip and Larry reading copies of "The Tantr Yoga of Sex". And spitting tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Kid from Lynchburg wasn't good  enough to hold Crash's jockstrap if  ya ask me, and Nuke's replacement  had a fastball that I coulda hit (beat) We had a three game lead with two  weeks to go when the rains came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE GROUND CREW DRAGS TARPS over the mound and the plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It rained and rained and I thought  of driving down to Asheville to see  Crash but then I thought "No, what  you pursue, eludes you". I had to  trust Quantum Physics and the Church  of Baseball. (beat) It ain't always easy being this  religious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE AND JACKSON POP OPEN THEIR UMBRELLAS and walk out o the ballpark towards home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE AND JACKSON UNDER UMBRELLAS -- He turns down one st she heads toward home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AS SHE APPROACHES -- She stops. Looks up. Crash's beat up car in the driveway. P.O.V.  CRASH SITTING ON THE PORCH SWING Still raining. CLOSE ON ANNIE -- She hesitates, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANNIE SITS DOWN on the porch owing next to Crash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I quit. Hit my dinger and hung 'em  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of silence over the significance of him quitting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm quitting too. Boys, not baseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There might be an opening for a  manager at Salem next spring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salem, Massachusetts? Where all the  witches were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... you a witch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. It takes years of practice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles slightly and takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I could make it to the  Show as a manager?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be great, just great... (rattling quickly) 'Cause you understand non-linear  thinking even though it seems like  baseball is a linear game 'cause of  the lines and the box scores an'   all -- but the fact is that there's  a spacious-"non-time kind of time"  to it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Annie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a lotta time to hear your  theories and I wanta hear every damn  one of 'em... but right now I'm tired  and I don't wanta think about baseball  and I don't wanta think about Quantum  Physics... I don't wanta think about  nothing... (beat) I just wanta be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises, takes her hand, and they head inside. And as the rains fall on Durham...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SHRINE GLOWS -- Candles everywhere. Rain pours down o the windows outside. And... ANNIE AND CRASH SIT ON THE COUCH together, in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walt Whitman once said -- "I see  great things in baseball. It's our  game -- the American game (beat) He said "it will repair our losses  and be a blessing to us"... (beat) You could look it up....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music -- Dave Frishberg sings "Van Lingle Mungo".
